item.title: Hacking of Trading Accounts in Japan Spreads to Mid-Sized Firms
item.description: Criminals have targeted mid-sized brokerages in Japan after the country’s biggest securities firms added additional protection for online trading.
item.dc:creator: Ryo Horiuchi

media:content.media:description: A stream of binary coding, text or computer processor instructions, is seen displayed on a laptop computer screen as a man works to enter data on the computer keyboard in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Wednesday, Dec. 23, 2015. The U.K.s biggest banks fear cyber attacks more than regulation, faltering economic growth and other potential risks, and are concerned that a hack could be so catastrophic that it could lead to a state rescue, according to a survey. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe

item.title: LNG Traders Look to Increase Exports to Malaysia, Indonesia
item.description: Liquefied natural gas traders are looking to sell more of the fuel to traditional exporters in Southeast Asia that are being forced to turn to imports to meet surging energy needs.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Sing Yee Ong

media:content.media:description: The LNG Aquarius liquefied natural gas tanker at Java Sea offshore in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Sunday, Oct. 31, 2021. The world is facing an energy crisis, with demand rebounding as economies reopen after the pandemic. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

item.title: WTO Chief ' Very Encouraged' on China-US Trade Truce
item.description: WTO Director Generral Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala says she's 'very encouraged' by the easing of US-China tensions and calls for further progress, observing that the contraction in global goods trade contraction is already lessening. She spoke to Bloomberg's Chief North Asia Correspondent Stephen Engle on the sidelines of the APEC meeting in Jeju, South Korea. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Dollar Weakens as Trade-Driven Moves Moderate: Markets Wrap
item.description: The dollar weakened for a second session while equities slipped, as large market moves earlier in the week driven by the US-China tariff truce moderated.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

media:content.media:description: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average inside the Kabuto One building in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, April 8, 2025. Shares in Asia rebounded after posting a historic loss, as Japan led gains on expectations that it will get priority in US trade talks. Treasuries gained after Monday’s sharp selloff. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: India Airports End Turkish Firm’s Services Over Pakistan Row
item.description: India stopped a Turkish company from operating at its airports after Turkey voiced support for Pakistan during a recent conflict between the two South Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Taylan Bilgic, Mihir Mishra

media:content.media:description: An aircraft flies over Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi, India, on Tuesday, Aug. 24, 2021. India plans to raise 6 trillion rupees ($81 billion) by leasing out state-owned infrastructure assets over the next four years to fund new capital expenditure without pressuring government finances. The proposal involves handing assets including roads, railways, airports, sports stadiums, power transmission lines and gas pipelines to private operators.

item.title: Foreigners Revisit Indonesia Stocks on Easing Economic Concerns
item.description: Indonesian stocks are poised for their first monthly inflow since September as subsiding economic concerns and attractive banking shares lure investors.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani

item.title: Leonardo CEO Cingolani: Almost in a War Economy
item.description: Roberto Cingolani, CEO of Italian defense company Leonardo, discusses Europe's defense buildup and outlook with Bloomberg's Tommaso Ebhardt at the company's headquarters in Rome. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ice Cream Inflation Arrives Just in Time for Summer
item.description: Coconut oil, a key ingredient in our favorite sweet treat, is becoming very expensive.
item.dc:creator: Javier Blas

item.title: Malaysia Central Bank Says It’s Ready to Act as Growth View Dims
item.description: Malaysia’s central bank said it has the policy room to act as it expects economic growth to fall below the official forecast this year, with US tariffs dimming the outlook for the trade-reliant nation.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry, Kok Leong Chan

item.title: Tariff Truce Spurs Pacific Trade Rush, Boosting Global Shippers
item.description: Importers rushing to ship Chinese goods to the US using a short reprieve from paralyzing tariffs could provide a much-needed boost to global freighters.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo, Chloe Meley

item.title: Romania’s Destiny Rides on Trump Follower Versus Math Prodigy
item.description: Romania’s track record as a reliable supporter of the European project will be put to the test Sunday as an ultranationalist Donald Trump disciple contends for the presidency against a one-time math prodigy.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu, Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan, left, and George Simion during a live election debate in Bucharest, on May 8.

item.title: India Examining US Request to Abolish Curbs on Ethanol Imports
item.description: India is reviewing a US request to lift restrictions on ethanol imports as it negotiates a wider trade deal with Washington to avoid punitive tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Pratik Parija, Rakesh Sharma, Shruti Srivastava

item.title: Chinese Gold Miner Chifeng Scours Globe for Takeover Targets
item.description: A major Chinese gold producer is scouting for acquisition opportunities around the world, although the recent price volatility driven by global trade turmoil means it’s not rushing to secure deals.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Sybilla Gross, Chongjing Li

media:content.media:description: Chifeng Gold’s Wassa Mine in Ghana. Source: Chifeng Gold

item.title: 'Quite Attractive' Opportunities in Asian Bonds, BlackRock's Saigal Says
item.description: BlackRock's Navin Saigal says the current environment is "an exciting one" and perhaps what most investors "are not entirely used to." Saigal tells Bloomberg Television that "what is inflationary at the margin for the US could be deflationary for China and the rest of Asia." He says the disinflationary or deflationary trend is real, but it also creates a huge opportunity for bond investors to add a diversified market to their portfolios. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Holds Decline as Potential Iran Deal Raises Supply Concerns
item.description: Oil was steady after two days of losses as a potential nuclear deal between the US and Iran risks exacerbating a glut forecast for later this year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Production facilities for ethane, methanol and sulfur petrochemicals stand at the Bushehr Petrochemical Co. plant during construction work in the Pars Special Economic and Energy Zone in Asaluyeh, Iran, on Monday, July 8, 2019. Shipping in the Middle East is getting ever riskier, with a standoff between the U.K. navy and Iran just the latest in a line of incidents in the region over the past few months. Photographer: Ali Mohammadi/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s BlissBio Is Said to Be Considering Hong Kong IPO
item.description: BlissBio, a Chinese company that develops treatments for cancer, is considering an initial public offering in Hong Kong, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Pei Li, Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: The flags of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR), left, China, second left, and the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx), second right, in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, Feb. 29, 2024. Hong Kong’s stock exchange posted a 13% decline in fourth quarter profit as trading declined and initial public offerings remained weak. Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Disinflation Wave Set to Boost Emerging-Market Bonds
item.description: A wave of Chinese exports redirected toward emerging markets is likely to help crimp inflation across the developing world and bolster longer-maturity bonds, fund managers say.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Bosley, Mary Nicola

item.title: Distressed Hong Kong Builder Parkview Gets Private Loan From PAG
item.description: Hong Kong’s Parkview Group has obtained a HK$300 million ($38 million) private credit loan from investment firm PAG, according to a person familiar with the matter, as banks grow reluctant to extend funds to the cash-strapped developer.
item.dc:creator: Apple Ka Ying Li, Pearl Liu, Megawati Wijaya

media:content.media:description: The Hong Kong Parkview apartment complex. Photographer: Justin Chin

item.title: India’s Midcaps Beat Larger Peers in Earnings Growth
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: Carlyle Japan's Tomioka on Japan's PE Market
item.description: Takaomi Tomioka, Co-head at Carlyle Japan, discusses the investment opportunities in Japan's private equity markets. He speaks with Shery Ahn on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: LG Chem Seeks $1 Billion for Bonds Exchangeable Into LG Energy Solution Shares
item.description: LG Energy Solution Ltd.’s stock slipped to a fresh record low, as a plan by its parent LG Chem Ltd. to refinance exchangeable bonds spurred dilution concerns over the EV battery maker.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian

media:content.media:description: The LG Chem Ltd. plant in the Yeosu Industrial Complex in South Korea.

item.title: Ex-RBA Board Member Urges Rate Pause on High Fiscal Spending
item.description: Australia’s “very large” fiscal stimulus at a time when monetary policy is around neutral — neither stimulating nor slowing economic activity — suggests the Reserve Bank should keep interest rates unchanged next week, former board member Warwick McKibbin said.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Malaysia Committed to 2025 Petrol Subsidy Cut But No Fixed Date
item.description: Malaysia is committed to reducing petrol subsidies in the second half of the year and is refining its plan as US tariffs darken the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Netty Idayu Ismail

media:content.media:description: Customers refuel RON95 petrol at a gas station.

item.title: Hillhouse’s First Private Credit Fund to Raise Some $700 Million
item.description: Elham Credit Partners, the private credit arm of Hillhouse Investment, is set to get anchor commitments of $700 million to $750 million for the first close of its inaugural private credit fund, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Kari Soo Lindberg

media:content.media:description: Buildings in Singapore, on Monday, March 10, 2025. Economists lowered the growth outlook for Singapore and Hong Kong in the second half of this year on increased uncertainties from US President Donald Trump imposing higher tariffs on China’s exports, according to the median of a Bloomberg survey. Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Baidu, Bilibili, Lenovo Report as US-China Trade Tensions Ease
item.description: Baidu Inc., Bilibili Inc. and Lenovo Group Ltd. are among the Chinese tech firms in focus for next week’s earnings, just as the easing US-China trade war brings back some optimism for the sector.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo, Justina T Lee, Harshita Swaminathan, Reina Sasaki

media:content.media:description: A screen demonstrates a Taichi learning software utilizing AI and motion capture technology during the Baidu Inc. Create AI Developer Conference in Wuhan, China, on Friday, April 25, 2025. Baidu unveiled upgrades to its flagship AI models and slashed their prices as it looks to take on rivals like Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. and DeepSeek in China's increasingly competitive artificial intelligence market.

item.title: S&P 500 Rises as Fed-Cut Bets Sink Treasury Yields | Bloomberg: The Close 05/15/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Scott Chronert, Citi, David Hunt, PGIM, David Bellinger, Mizuho, Mandeep Singh, Bloomberg Intelligence, Ellen Zentner, Morgan Stanley Wealth Mgmt, Mark Gurman, Bloomberg News, Que Nguyen, Research Affiliates, Hans Humes, Greylock Capital, Courtney Rickert McCaffrey, EY, Rashaun Williams, Harbinger Sports Partners, Bridgit Mendler, Northwood. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nissan Plans to Shuts Plants After Worst Loss in Years
item.description: Nissan Motor Co. vowed to close seven factories and slash 20,000 jobs after posting one of its biggest annual losses since French carmaker Renault SA rescued it from near bankruptcy a quarter century ago.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Takahashi

media:content.media:description: Ivan Espinosa in Yokohama on May 13.

item.title: Meat Firm Marfrig Makes Offer for Remaining BRF Stake
item.description: Marfrig Global Foods SA, a leading Brazilian meat producer, agreed to acquire the shares it doesn’t already own in the country’s top chicken firm, BRF SA.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Gamarski, Clarice Couto, Vinicius Andrade

media:content.media:description: A butcher cuts meat at a grocery store in Brasilia, Brazil, on Monday, March 29, 2021. Brazil, the country renowned globally for its churrascaria steaks, is battling a vicious Covid-19 outbreak that shows no sign of peaking, and its economic consequences are visible in the diet of middle-class Brazilians. Photographer: Victor Moriyama/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Surging Yields Put Policymakers in a Difficult Position
item.description: After years of moving at a glacial pace, yields in Japan’s $7.8 trillion government debt market are shifting higher at breakneck speed.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Masaki Kondo

item.title: World’s Biggest Sugar Trader Slashes Estimate for Global Surplus
item.description: The world’s biggest sugar trader slashed its forecast for a global surplus in the coming season, cautioning that the market was underestimating risks from weather and transportation in top grower Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Ilena Peng

media:content.media:description: A worker shovels sugar at the Vista Alegre sugar and ethanol bioenergy plant in Itapetininga, Sao Paulo state, Brazil, on Friday, Nov. 10, 2023. Sugar mills returning from the ashes are helping drive up production of the commodity in top producer Brazil, a key move to aid tight global markets as other producing countries face several crop issues. Photographer: Jonne Roriz/Bloomberg
